content.title: Neurorehabilitation
content.summary: Neurorehabilitation is a multidisciplinary approach to maximize functional recovery after neurological injury. It encompasses physical, occupational, speech, and cognitive therapy tailored to specific deficits. Neuroplasticity forms the biological basis for recovery, with intensive, task-specific, repetitive practice driving neural reorganization and functional improvement.
key_points: Multidisciplinary team: PT, OT, SLP, neuropsychology, nursing, social work
Neuroplasticity: Neural reorganization enables recovery; use-dependent plasticity
Intensity matters: More therapy hours correlate with better outcomes
Task-specific training: Practice functional tasks relevant to daily life
Spasticity management: Stretching, splinting, botulinum toxin, intrathecal baclofen
Constraint-induced movement therapy (CIMT): Restrains unaffected limb to force use of affected limb
content.statement: Neurorehabilitation leverages neuroplasticity through intensive, task-specific, multidisciplinary therapy to maximize functional recovery after stroke, TBI, spinal cord injury, and other neurological conditions.

explanation.intuition: Think of the brain after injury like a city with damaged roads. Neurorehabilitation is like the city rerouting traffic and building new roads around the damage. The more you practice a route (repetitive task-specific training), the better and faster that new road becomes (neuroplasticity). If you don't use it, the road falls into disrepair (use it or lose it).
explanation.key_insight: Recovery follows a predictable time course: most rapid recovery occurs in the first 3 months, with continued but slower gains over 6-12 months. The 'critical period' after injury represents a window of enhanced plasticity. Therapy intensity during this period has the greatest impact on long-term outcomes.
explanation.technical_details: Neuroplasticity mechanisms include: axonal sprouting, unmasking of latent pathways, long-term potentiation, synaptogenesis. Motor learning principles apply: massed vs distributed practice, whole vs part task training, explicit vs implicit learning. Brunnstrom stages describe motor recovery after stroke.

definitions_glossary.neurorehabilitation: Multidisciplinary intervention to restore function after neurological injury
definitions_glossary.neuroplasticity: Brain's ability to reorganize structure and function in response to injury or experience
definitions_glossary.physical_therapy: PT - mobility, gait, balance, transfer training, therapeutic exercise
definitions_glossary.occupational_therapy: OT - activities of daily living (ADLs), fine motor, upper extremity function
definitions_glossary.speech_language_pathology: SLP - speech, language, cognition, swallowing disorders
definitions_glossary.constraint_induced_movement_therapy: CIMT - forces use of affected limb by restraining unaffected side
definitions_glossary.spasticity: Velocity-dependent increase in muscle tone from upper motor neuron lesion
definitions_glossary.Brunnstrom_stages: Motor recovery phases: flaccidity → spasticity → voluntary movement
definitions_glossary.task_specific_training: Practice of functional tasks relevant to patient's real-life activities
definitions_glossary.FIM: Functional Independence Measure - standardized rehabilitation outcome scale
definitions_glossary.intrathecal_baclofen: Pump delivering baclofen to spinal cord for severe spasticity

pathophysiology.mechanism: Recovery from neurological injury occurs through neuroplasticity - the brain's ability to reorganize neural networks, with rehabilitation providing the environmental stimulation to drive adaptive changes

recovery_phases.acute: Days 1-7: Medical stabilization, prevention of complications
recovery_phases.subacute: Weeks 1-12: Intensive rehabilitation during enhanced plasticity window
recovery_phases.chronic: Months to years: Maintenance, community reintegration, long-term adaptation

occupational_therapy.focus: Meaningful activities relevant to patient's life roles

definition.@value: A multidisciplinary approach using physical, occupational, and speech therapy to maximize functional recovery after neurological injury through neuroplasticity-driven interventions

scopeNote.@value: Covers principles, assessment, and interventions in neurorehabilitation

learning_objectives: Describe the biological basis of neuroplasticity and recovery
Identify roles of multidisciplinary rehabilitation team members
Apply motor learning principles to rehabilitation interventions
Manage spasticity using conservative and pharmacologic approaches
Assess functional outcomes using standardized measures
clinical_pearls: First 3 months = critical window for most rapid recovery; maximize therapy intensity
CIMT works but requires 3-6 hours/day of practice for 2-3 weeks
Spasticity can be useful (helps with standing/transfers); don't always treat aggressively
Depression common post-stroke (30-50%); screen and treat to improve rehab participation
Mirror therapy: watching unaffected limb move while imagining affected limb moving
common_misconceptions: Recovery stops after 6 months - improvements can continue for years with therapy
More therapy is always better - optimal dosing exists; fatigue can limit gains
Spasticity is always bad - can be functionally useful; selective treatment indicated
